Document Title: Quantum Computing for Undergraduate Engineering Students: Report of an Experience
Author Affiliations: Universidad de Montevideo, Montevideo, Uruguay; Universidad de Montevideo, Montevideo, Uruguay
Publication Title: 2021 IEEE International Conference on Quantum Computing and Engineering (QCE)
Abstract: This paper presents the experience of a Quantum Computer course addressed for the first time for undergraduate engineering students. Students’ levels varied from year two to five of their careers and had previous knowledge on Calculus, Linear Algebra and Programming, but not on Quantum Mechanics or on Modern Physics. The main objective of the course was that students acquire programming skills in Quantum Computing, so it had a practical approach. Instead of beginning by introducing the physical phenomenology under the field, the course started directly with presenting the logic of quantum computing from an abstract point of view. The language used was Q#. The curricula was based on the one available for the Microsoft Quantum Network.
IEEE Terms: Three-dimensional displays;Engineering profession;Quantum mechanics;Virtual environments;Linear algebra;Calculus;Quantum networks

Document Title: Quantum circuit design using neural networks assisted by entanglement
Authors: C. Allende; E. Buksman; A. F. De Oliveira
Author Affiliations: Faculty of Engineering, Universidad ORT, Montevideo, Uruguay; Faculty of Engineering, Universidad ORT, Montevideo, Uruguay; Faculty of Engineering, Universidad ORT, Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: This work introduces a novel structure based on universal quantum circuits which uses classical machine learning techniques in order to solve a quantum problem: the decomposition of a generic quantum operator into a sequence of elementary unitary matrices (universal basic quantum gates). Even though the postulates of quantum mechanics guarantee any unitary operation as a feasible operation over a quantum system, there is no simple method to implement an arbitrary algorithm. By means of a multilayer hybrid neural network in which the basic cell is made up of CNOTs and universal one-qubit unitary gates, this work offers a solution to the given problem. These specific gates were chosen since they are the gates available in real quantum computers such as IBMQ's quantum processors. The network learns the unitary gates classically using the method of the steepest descent and is aided in learning the entangling gates by the use of two types of quantum correlations: Mutual Information (MI) and Cumulative Correlation Measure (CCM). The algorithm implemented in this case is a type of supervised learning. The results show that the model fits the data gracefully and correctly predicts a wide range of algorithms.
IEEE Terms: Training;Knowledge engineering;Quantum system;Correlation;Neural networks;Supervised learning;Machine learning
INSPEC Controlled Terms: learning (artificial intelligence);matrix algebra;quantum computing;quantum entanglement;quantum gates;quantum theory

Document Title: Preparing for the Quantum Future: Perspectives of an Entrepreneurial Innovator
Author Affiliations: Universidad de Montevideo, Montevideo, Uruguay; Harrisburg University of Science and Technology, Harrisburg, PA, USA
Abstract: Commercial use of quantum computing technology is in our future, and the CEO of one quantum technology company is positioning his company to deliver a first-mover advantage for enterprises. However, the focus is on satisfying customers today, so he is—without pause—preparing customers to leverage the most advanced quantum technology today and into the future. Christopher Savoie, a serial entrepreneur and a founder of Zapata Computing, recently discussed his views on innovation processes, forming companies around emergent technologies, and how he is building a business within the nascent quantum computing industry.

Document Title: Quantum Computing Entrepreneurship and IEEE TEMS
Abstract: Quantum computing is experiencing an inflection point. This technology is likely to facilitate great advances in many fields including logistics, chemistry simulation, or even risk analysis. It is attractive for large hardware and software companies in addition to start-up entrepreneurial enterprises. In this article, we summarize interesting insights into this field related to possibilities related to quantum computing and entrepreneurship.
Author Keywords: Diffusion of ITT innovations;entrepreneurship;information and telecommunication technologies;quantum computing (QC)

Document Title: Managing a Quantum Computing Team—Insights and Challenges at Itaú Unibanco
Authors: R. Sotelo; T. L. Frantz; S. Brito; V. F. da Silva; A. J. Ferreira Martins; I. Bernardes-Urias
Author Affiliations: Universidad de Montevideo, Montevideo, Uruguay; Harrisburg University of Science and Technology, Harrisburg, PA, USA; Banco Itaú Unibanco, Sao Paulo, Sao Paulo, Brazil; Banco Itaú Unibanco, Sao Paulo, Sao Paulo, Brazil; Banco Itaú Unibanco, Sao Paulo, Sao Paulo, Brazil; Banco Itaú Unibanco, Sao Paulo, Sao Paulo, Brazil
Abstract: Quantum computing technology is developing rapidly. Technology managers are now faced with pressure to bring the emerging technology in-house, albeit perhaps stealthy. This article presents the story of a large Brazilian financial services firm that is facing the quantum “opportunity” head-on. We provide insights into the challenge of introducing nonproven technology to this one particular organization. In addition to team-level management, other aspects in the realm of organization-level issues are presented including expectation setting, reporting, and budgeting.

Document Title: Supplierthon Methodology: The 2021 BMW Quantum Computing Challenge
Author Affiliations: Universidad de Montevideo, Montevideo, Uruguay; Harrisburg University of Science and Technology, Harrisburg, PA, USA
Abstract: The “Supplierthon” methodology is BMW Group's supplier scouting method that can be especially effective for identifying partners in R&D projects. This article describes the supplierthon methodology developed at BMW and reports on how it was applied as the company sought to identify new partners for its entry into quantum computing. In total, three members of BMW's quantum computing and business development team are interviewed to learn how the process works, how it was applied to the case of quantum computing, and what the outcomes were—both expected and unexpected.

Document Title: Applications of quantum computing to optimization
Author Affiliations: Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de Montevideo, Montevideo, Uruguay
Publication Title: 2021 IEEE CHILEAN Conference on Electrical, Electronics Engineering, Information and Communication Technologies (CHILECON)
Abstract: The paper presents the basic aspects of the logic behind Quantum Computing and shows its fields of application and the state of the industry, focusing on the special case of the work at Universidad de Montevideo and the startup Quantum-South, born within it: optimization applications for air cargo transport and investment portfolio optimization applications. The paper content has been presented in a plenary session at IEEE CHILECON 2021. It has been intended to motivate professionals and students to work on Quantum Computing in the field of optimization.

Document Title: Application of quantum optimization techniques (QUBO method) to cargo logistics on ships and airplanes
Authors: F. Hernández; K. Díaz; M. Forets; R. Sotelo
Author Affiliations: Universidad de Montevideo, Uruguay; Universidad de Montevideo, Uruguay; Universidad de Montevideo, Uruguay; Universidad de Montevideo, Uruguay
Abstract: The video (https://youtu.be/qB07ueMVw0w) presents our ongoing work on the optimization of cargo logistics processes with containers using quantum computing, mainly in airplanes and barges, of great international relevance. Combinatorial optimization problems are computationally complex in conventional computing. The origins of Quantum Computing date back to the early 90's. This discipline allows solving problems that in conventional computing are complex [1]. We present a Quantum Computing tool, the QUBO method (Quadratic Unconstrained Binary Optimization) [2], which is suitable for formulating combinatorial optimization problems. QUBO is a recently developed tool, based on Quantum Annealing and is implemented in some current quantum computers. It consists of minimizing outputs of the type xTQx with x being a binary decision vector and Q a square or triangular matrix with constant parameters provided by the model. Restrictions can be added to the treated system. These problems have to do with making good decisions in environments where a large number of binary decisions (Yes/No) must be made and each set of decisions produces a corresponding objective function value, such as a cost or benefit value. In the video we also present the example of the Number Partitioning Problem.
INSPEC Controlled Terms: aircraft;boats;combinatorial mathematics;computational complexity;freight handling;logistics;optimisation;quadratic programming;quantum computing
INSPEC Non-Controlled Terms: combinatorial optimization problems;quantum annealing;quantum computers;binary decision vector;number partitioning problem;quantum optimization techniques;ships;airplanes;cargo logistics;barges;quantum computing;Quadratic Unconstrained Binary Optimization method;QUBO method

Author Affiliations: Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de Montevideo, Montevideo, Uruguay
Publication Title: 2019 IEEE CHILEAN Conference on Electrical, Electronics Engineering, Information and Communication Technologies (CHILECON)
Abstract: This paper provides an introductory reading about Quantum Computing (QC). It describes what is called QC, how does it work and the benefits it provides, naming some famous algorithms. It includes a review on the fields of application that QC is expected to fulfil, and the status of the QC ecosystem. The paper content has been presented in a plenary session at IEEE Chilecon 2019. It has been intended to motivate professionals and students to work on QC.

Authors: A. Díaz-Caro; M. Guillermo; A. Miquel; B. Valiron
Author Affiliations: Instituto de Ciencias de la Computación (UBA-CONICET), Buenos Aires, Argentina; Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; Facultad de Ingeniería, Universidad de la República, Montevideo, Uruguay; LRI, Université Paris-Saclay, Orsay, France
Publication Title: 2019 34th Annual ACM/IEEE Symposium on Logic in Computer Science (LICS)
Abstract: In this paper we present a semantics for a linear algebraic lambda-calculus based on realizability. This semantics characterizes a notion of unitarity in the system, answering a long standing issue. We derive from the semantics a set of typing rules for a simply-typed linear algebraic lambda-calculus, and show how it extends both to classical and quantum lambda-calculi.

Document Title: Testing Methods for Measuring the Effects of Stray Capacitances on High-Voltage Current Transformers
Authors: G. Aristoy; A. Santos; D. Slomovitz
Author Affiliations: UTE Laboratory, National Electrical Power Utility, Montevideo, Uruguay; UTE Laboratory, National Electrical Power Utility, Montevideo, Uruguay; UTE Laboratory, National Electrical Power Utility, Montevideo, Uruguay
Publication Title: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
Abstract: This paper evaluates different measuring systems to estimate the effect of stray capacitances between primary and secondary windings on current transformers (CTs) used in high-voltage power networks. All windings are at nearly ground potential during laboratory calibration because this is the typical configuration for almost all CT's calibration systems. However, in service, the primary winding is at high potential, so that additional currents flow through the load due to stray capacitances between primary and secondary windings, even if the CT has an electrostatic shield for reducing these capacitances. This effect changes the CT errors determined at no potential. Experimental determination of the variation of ratio and phase displacement errors between both working conditions is evaluated for a set of different CTs using different measuring systems. These systems include from the simplest low-voltage bridge capacitance measurement to the most complex one that simultaneously applies current and voltage.
Author Keywords: Current transformer (CT);high voltage (HV);instrument transformer;isolation;parasitic capacitance;test.;Current transformer (CT);high voltage (HV);instrument transformer;isolation;parasitic capacitance;test

Document Title: Force Sensing Resistors Used as Plantar Impedance Plethysmography Electrodes
Authors: I. Morales; R. González-Landaeta; F. Simini
Author Affiliations: Hospital de Clínicas, Núcleo de Ingeniería Biomédica, Universidad de la Répública, Montevideo, Uruguay; Departamento de Ingeniería Eléctrica y Computación, Universidad Autónoma de Ciudad Juárez, Ciudad Juarez, Chihuaha, Mexico; Hospital de Clínicas, Núcleo de Ingeniería Biomédica, Universidad de la Répública, Montevideo, Uruguay
Publication Title: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
Abstract: Diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs) are an ominous consequence of diabetic foot. To develop a multidimensional lesion warning device, several variables must be considered, among which vascular parameters. To minimize the number of sensors, we investigate the use of standard flexible force sensing resistors (FSRs), FSR402 and FSR406, to detect not only plantar pressure but also bioimpedance plethysmography. Since FSRs include conductive electrodes covered by polymer film, the interface with the subject can be considered a capacitive electrode. We present a special impedance plethysmography (IPG) circuit to inject current using FSRs and measuring the resulting voltage from other FSRs contacts. IPG simulations with two modeled FSRs, two contacts each, were not successful, but using four FSRs, one capacitive contact each, shows a precision within 4% of the expected FSR resistor value. The IPG system was verified with simultaneously matching ECG-lead I, Ag–AgCl, and capacitive electrode signals alongside power spectra. For the first time, four sole pressure sensors are used also as bioimpedance electrodes to detect cardiac activity with standard components at frequencies up to 50 kHz and simulated as well as experimentally verified on one healthy subject.
Author Keywords: Bioimpedance;diabetic foot ulcer (DFU);force sensing resistor (FSR);impedance plethysmography (IPG);plantar electrodes;wearable device
